text: You’re just leaving the hospital, beaming with pride and excited to finally go home with baby {{Child.name}}. A nurse comes up to finish some last minute preparations.

speaker: nurse
text: Babies! Gotta love them! The joy, the pain, the responsibility. It’s a lot for new parents to handle, especially in the first few months. Up for the challenge?

speaker: nurse
text: You can do it! Just follow the advice my grandma gave me when I became a parent. She said, “If you can’t take care of yourself, how can you take care of a baby?”
moreInfo: Babies require a lot of care and up to 80% of new mothers experience "baby blues," or feelings of worry, unhappiness, and fatigue that last a week or two. Some new moms experience a more severe form of depression known as postpartum depression, which can be managed by prompt treatment.

choices.text: What does she mean by that?

speaker: nurse
text: I didn’t know what she meant...until she shared her seven secrets to living healthy. Eat right. Drink water. Exercise. Get good sleep. Take breaks. See your doctor. Get vaccinated.

speaker: nurse
text: Vaccines save lives! You should talk with your doctor about immunization. I kept my child’s pediatrician on speed dial. So helpful to talk with someone I could trust for information about my family’s health.

speaker: nurse
text: I like you, so I’ll also throw in my grandma’s recipe for chicken soup. Everyone loves it! And by the way, take those extra diapers home...you’ll need em!

choices.text: Wow! It feel like I’ve hit jackpot!

speaker: nurse
text: Ok then, I won’t keep you waiting. Off you go! Don’t forget those secrets. Eat right. Drink water. Exercise. Get good sleep. See your doctor. Get vaccinated.

choices.text: Living and breathing your advice as we speak!
Thank you, I have to go.

text: Home sweet home. It's your first night back home with {{Child.name}}, and you're nervous but excited at this new chapter in your life. You carry {{Child.name}} over to {{Child.pronoun.his}} crib, hoping not to wake {{Child.pronoun.him}}. You place {{Child.pronoun.him}} gently in {{Child.pronoun.his}} own bed...

You remembered that your doctor had advised you to place {{Child.name}} on {{Child.pronoun.his}} back while sleeping to prevent SIDS. And you've just followed her advice to a T! A wave of confidence suddenly washes over you as you realize that you've conquered the first steps in keeping {{Child.name}} healthy!
moreInfo: The risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) can be minimized by placing babies on their back for sleep, and by not bed-sharing. Have a conversation with your child's provider if you have any questions or concerns to discuss the best options for keeping your child healthy.

text: You place {{Child.name}} into the crib on {{Child.pronoun.his}} side. {{Child.pronoun.he}} looks so peaceful, but you can't help feeling like there's something that you've forgotten....

choices.text: What did the doctor say about sleeping?

text: Suddenly, you recall the saying that babies should be placed on their backs while sleeping to prevent SIDS! Glad you remembered this fact, you quickly turn {{Child.name}} so that {{Child.pronoun.he}} is now sleeping on his back.
moreInfo: The risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) can be minimized by placing babies on their back for sleep, and by not bed-sharing. Have a conversation with your child's provider if you have any questions or concerns to discuss the best options for keeping your child healthy.

text: As you finally crawl into your own bed, you begin to wonder. What kind of person will {{Child.name}} be? What kind of parent will you be? How will you keep {{Child.name}} healthy?
Before you know it, you begin to doze off. The thoughts drifting away, one by one, until there is only the peacefulness of you and {{Child.name}} fast asleep.
